commentBody:
One of the laziest and easiest Wednesday puzzles I've ever done.

Boring theme, very average fill, forgettable clueing, and not in the least challenging.

1.5/10
The answer for 47A seems more like a "situation" than a "style" of fighting, but i guess it's about the wordplay. I got the theme quickly, and it's witty.

Thought I might be the first to comment tonight, but no. 

I liked it. Went fairly fast. Always fun for me no matter how easy it might be.

When it comes to seasons, summer better than others.

(Of fall the puns I could've chosen.)
MAN O MAN, that was an easy puzzle and theme.

Almost got skunked today. You didn't know the pain relief brand was spelled ANACIN, which I didn't, you'd be justified in thinking ANASIN was the correct spelling and that 52A was TASK.

Also, shame there's not a country that only has AIL in the name...

There was a lot of GLUE in this one: ERIE, ICEE, EDAM and ERR, but no Oreo.

Is there a name for the species of anagram used in this puzzle where the answer uses only the letters of the clue, but can reuse letters?

That was a fun one! And fairly easy for me on a Wednesday. I hope y‚Äôall enjoyed it, too. Thanks,  Neville! All y‚Äôall have a great Wednesday! And GO YANKEES! You have to win or we go home. Please make my Wednesday awesome!

I know it‚Äôs customary, or at least traditional, to have anagram clues in all caps. I feel that in this case, however, I would have preferred the clues not use all caps, and just a question mark perhaps. The puzzle was too easy knowing what letters made up the theme clues, and having to eventually figure that out would have at least provided for an Aha moment.
Enjoyed the puzzle tonight. Thought it was perfect for a Wednesday.
Easy sailing in the north, took some thinking at the 45* parallel.   Very nicely done.  Didn‚Äôt need a revealer, just patience.

Neville must be one of those "globalists" you hear of on certain podcasts!

A better, more fluffy risotto from America?
CREAMIER RICE

An elderly Robert Burns from South America?
RHEUMATIC SCOT

What Piazza San Marco can loan us from Singapore?
SPARE PIGEONS

A delicacy from Iceland?
CANDIED LICE

And one last one, speaking of Slovenia...

Certain White House NFT products from Melanesia?
[The First Lady's] MEANIES SELL ENAMEL ANIMEE ANIMALS IN EMAILS...

I tend to disagree with the opinion that it was too easy for a Wednesday. I found it a little chewy for a Monday. Took me a while to figure out PAELLA pan and I am not into European beers. So I think the ease depends on your knowledge. However, was still 2 minutes under my average

I like the crossing of Asahi and Amstel.  

It‚Äôs been a minute since I‚Äôve had paella.  Maybe need to cook some up this weekend.

a wednesday served up with a fillip of thursday.
tasty.

I think Mel Taub is smiling down on us. I didn't catch that the themer anagrams were all names of countries until I read the constructor notes. Maybe Wednesdays DO need a title. Thank you, Mr. Fogarty!

(I don't usually do the puzzle on its eve, but I'm staying up to watch the Fever. ü§ûüèª)

Slow to start but gradually began to work my way out from the NW corner and gratefully everything started to click. The theme was pitched just right IMO. A helpful clue, but not so helpful that all the theme clues are a gimme once you've figured it out.

So close to beating it without assistance, but I genuinely had zero idea the note was SOL rather than SOH. Apparently it's sew in the song so I'll blame The Sound of Music.

That one I didn't mind but the ANACIN ERIE Natick was more frustrating. Is Anacin a household name in the US? We get exposed to lots of US brands over here but that one has never come up.

Guess this one was really in the wheelhouse for some folks who thought it was too easy --I hope y'all got great new record times from it!!
For me, I finished in a little under average time and found it a nice Wednesday, with some chuckles, plus places to puzzle things out and wait for the crosses.

The NW corner stumped me, since not knowing American football lingo I went for GoalBALL, which resulted in _RaYRANGER. I've heard of green and red berets, so why shouldn't there be gRaY RANGERS? (I did not fully understand the theme so I failed to spot M was missing). I have not heard of ORAL vaccines, so I kept staring at the _RoL I had there and feeling completely lost. Also, I was stumped by the "stole from a show" clue, especially with the wrong letter at the end. I had to resolve the resulting mess by checking the column.

As for BOA: Polish has the word "stola", which I think is related to the English "stole", but the meaning is slightly different. We have "boa" in Polish, too, but it's not a "stola". That word only means an ancient Roman gown and that thingie Catholic priests may wear over their shoulders.

Another problem spot was the crossing of the unfamiliar painkiller brand (crosses gave me ANA_IN) and the "bulletin board sticker" in the SW. I don't really know what a bulletin board is in English and I understood "sticker" as a thing you glue onto something, so with crosses giving me TA_K, I put an "s" there. I should have known better I guess. I looked up the drug in the end.

The theme was fine, but alas I wasn't observant enough to realize the answers used *only* letters from the themed countries. Doh.

There was so much trivia in the grid I was worried, initially. Ultimately of the proper and brand names only ANACIN caused problems (and autism, maybe? /Sigh).

For those who do the Saturday crossword in the Globe & Mail newspaper, the theme was a ‚Äúgimmee‚Äù.  It is one of the stock clue types that its constructor, Fraser Simpson, has been using in the more than 20 years he has been creating cryptic crosswords.  (His cryptic crosswords have appeared occasionally in the NYT.).

As I mentioned in my reply to John, I don‚Äôt understand the shade being thrown on this puzzle either?! I thought it was fun - I like Scrabble and Spelling Bee and who doesn‚Äôt like a good anagram? I almost got a PB tonight, but who cares? Some puzzles will be in your wheelhouse and others will be more challenging. I always appreciate what a constructor must have gone through to get to the point that their grid gets published. Thank you, Neville, for contributing to my daily fun.

When are the guardians of puzzle standards going to start giving us puzzles?  I long to see these exemplars of puzzledom that will represent the acme of day-of-the-week perfection, laid out before us, like patients etherized upon a table, ready for our awed approach, pencils and styluses poised, ready for the nirvana we will surely experience when we solve them.  

But we must try not to be disappointed when, despite the beauty of these dazzling, platinum standard jewels, there will be commenters who explain to us that they are actually duds.

The fun for me was when I got the theme on 17A. I hadn't filled in any of the theme answers, only a few letters, so I stopped with the downs and filled in the theme with their own clues. Cool. Nepalese paella, indeed. And a huge answer from just Oman, nice. Very clever! They all made me chuckle.

This one went very quickly for me until I became caught at 44D/52A. I had talk for a while and was purely guessing at the brand name. But got there eventually.

(Also initially guessed GoldBALL, which would be a nice reward though probably quite expensive.)

Having just done the Mel Taub PandAs yesterday, the theme leapt off the page.

Nice tribute.

The first crossword I've almost given up on because I don't know so many; so I revealed or looked up quite a few. 

Since some here thought it was really easy, it's just a culture/knowledge gap that's a bit too wide for me. 

I look forward to tomorrow!

I, at one point, had EDen at 20A.

I knew it was sealed. A red wax seal seemed...plausible, I guess.

Am I the only one who thought of Sha-Na-Na when trying to figure out 51A?
Didn't get into the swing of things with this one; thought there'd be more of a twist lurking about.

General observation:
After a Monday and a Tuesday that xwstats puzzlers found Hard (slower than average median solve time), an Average Wednesday (17% faster) would seem comparatively easy.

Personal  observation:
In crosswords, I prefer wordplay to letterplay.

Lovely theme idea, and it was fun to guess at the theme answers with as few crosses as possible.  That was my favorite part of this puzzle.

Excellent twist on the letter-bank genre, having the bank be a country name.

Crossnerd me was also impressed with what seems like a very tight theme, given its constrictions:
‚Ä¢	The country‚Äôs name can‚Äôt have any repeating letters.
‚Ä¢	All of its letters must be used.
‚Ä¢	The answers must be in-the-language phrases.

So, wow on that!  I was going to end this post with ‚ÄúGot to go!‚Äù, drawn from TOGO, but that wouldn‚Äôt have worked for this puzzle, as ‚ÄúTogo‚Äù has that repeating O.  Alas.

I liked the theme echoes in the grid ‚Äì LAILA ALI coming from the letters of ‚ÄúAil‚Äù (Hi, @Steven M!), and SAHARA coming from the letters of ‚Äúrash‚Äù.  I also liked the PuzzPair¬© of BREA and a backward TAR.

Sweet to see you back in the Times after nearly a five-year absence, Neville. Thank you for a fun and impressive outing!

Fun fact, schools never close due to bad weather in Finland. Kids go to school in snow storms, -30 etc. 
Also, it is very common here (at least where I've lived, can't speak for the capital) that even the very young kids walk or bike to school alone. That one was definitely a culture shock for me when I moved here.
Not too crazy about the Bowser cluing for WOOF. Avid Nintendo fan and the name for a dog never once popped into my mind.

Hi Will! This puzzle would have been tricky-funner without the IMPLICATION OF SHOUTING, say.

***

Anyone remember the Toledo War? As a former Ohioan/present Michigander, it is fresh in my memory! 

By the fourth decade of the 19th c., it was clear that the Maumee River, and the port of Toledo on Lake Erie, was going to become vital to water transport from the Eastern Seaboard to the (then) Western Frontier. But who owned it? Basing their claims on differing geographic surveys, and specifically the southern most point of Lake Michigan, there was an ten mile wide strip of land, running from Lake Erie to the Indiana, and which included the mouth of the Maumee, which was claimed by both the State of Ohio and Michigan Territory.

The issue came to a head in 1835, by which point Michigan was suing for statehood. However, Ohio would not approve, unless Michigan ceded its claims to the Toledo Strip, as it came to be called. Arguments grew hot, to the point that Ohio and Michgian both stationed militias on opposing sides of the Maumee; and one boozy Sunday night, volleys of musket fire were shot into the air (the Battle of Phillips Corners). Luckily, there were no casualties.

In December of 1836, at the Frostbitten Convention in Ann Arbor, Michigan finally ceded its claims. As a consolation prize, it received the Upper Peninsula from Wisconsin Territory, which, at the time, was considered worthless, but became economically valuable once copper was discovered there in the 1840's
The theme would have been better if it were subtler. As it was it was far too easy

Uhh, nothing. There needed to be a NOD to CCR.
All I could glean from this was Makers Mark and Sha-Na-Na.

I've never understood how commenters could call puzzle constructors "lazy".  I'm in awe of their skill and dedication to the game.
But -- and you knew there had to be a "but" -- there's something weak about using OMAN as the "letter bank" for MANO A MANO.
SLOVENIA for ALIEN INVASION?  Much more impressive.

And a note to Sam:  the themed answers not only use "only" the letters from their designated country, they use "all and only" those letters.

I can still hear Howard Cosell....

And as to 17A..."Elite soldier from GERMANY"--  Yikes.  
Given the current atmosphere/events, my immediate thought was:  Too Soon.

[Tagline for a movie featuring only actors playing themselves from USA]



US AS US
After Tuesday's delight, this one felt awfully flat. The theme was painfully obvious after the first clue. Nothing to write home about, just a very meh Wednesday puzzle done in Tuesday time.

My usual late puzzle find. A Saturday from March 26, 1983 by Sam Bellotto Jr. One theme clue and answer example: Daffy Duck? : CINEMALLARD And the other theme answers: PELICANTORS GUINEAPIGEON CIVILWARBLER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/26/1983&g=22&d=D ....

AMSTEL x SAHARA x ASAHI x MANOAMANO x SHAOLIN x ANACIN all crossing each other was... a choice.
i didn't realize the SW corner was a round of POTPOURRI in Jeopardy! 5 proper nouns crossing each other in 1 corner...

The international spirit of the theme reminded me of my travels to Europe.

I lived in FRANCE and RAN A CAFE

I moved to BELGIUM and owned a BIG MULE

I found the people of HUNGARY to be very friendly but received NARY A HUG 

I was bit by a dog in SERBIA and got RABIES

Where to go next? Since it‚Äôs WEDNESday I‚Äôll try SWEDEN.

See you tomorrow.

Is anagrammy a word? Well, it is today. I found the key when gebirgsjaeger didn't work in 17A. (Elite mountain troops from Germany.) I did want to see an actual "fighting style" in 47A, especially as it was directly above SHAOLIN kung fu. I have been trained in unarmed combat, AKA "hand-to-hand" so I'll give it a pass. One last thing; for fans of '80s music, here's 53A, by Alphaville: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nsKQlXkvgYI

What in the world was that? This was in__ltingly easy, even for a Monday, let alone a Wednesday. This ch_ld's level stuff doesn't belong in the New York Times!

What are the editors thinking?

(3rd expurgated try)

5 minutes of extensive research has revealed that ANACIN sponsored "Mary Kay and Johnny", the first TV sitcom.

In the United States!

As far as I can tell however, they did not sponsor the first sitcom, a British show called "Pinwright's Progress", which premiered one year earlier.

(I loved Pinwright's catchphrase, "I say, old chap, how you doin'?")(That last bit is the only part of this I made up.)
It's been so long since I used a bulletin board or thumb tacks that 52 across stumped me for a good while lol.

Maybe not surprising that this isn't the popular opinion of the early crowd but this is the first Wednesday in a while where I didn't gold star, having leaned on autocorrect to get this done. 

Brutal amounts of trivia crossing wordplay, many naticks.

If you don't know the trivia and haven't done crosswords for years, it's likely to be hard to get enough foothold to close this out.

Ignore the complainers who said this was too easy. Bully for them.

The trivia gap is huge on this one.

The theme was ok. I've had better and worse.

I strongly disagree with the columnists stating that people who do anagrams will solve this easily. I admit I find it annoying when they make statements like these as if they are universal. Not so.

I‚Äôm very grateful for the daily puzzle. I wouldn‚Äôt dream of criticizing the expected level for a given day. 

I enjoyed this one a lot. Thumbs up.

Love me some anagrams. Well done! Each letter used only once in the country name, and the solves comprising of only those letters? Chef's kiss! I didn't know ANACIN/ASAHI but guessed it could only be an "A", and I somehow pulled SHAOLIN out of the recesses (wasn't there a movie years ago called Shaolin Soccer?). 
Loved the clue for SAFE (and hope the M's stay SAFE through the weekend! ü§ûüèº)  
Lovely Wednesday!
Loved this.  Made me feel clever, although I guess it's the constructor who should get the credit.
So. many. proper. nouns. Pleeeeease ugh!!

Re Sam's column notes on 20A: I'm a longtime vegan but I got EDAM right away, maybe because I don't drink whiskey (or other alcoholic beverages) and have yet to receive a letter (threatening or otherwise) with a royal seal. :-)

Count me in the ‚Äúuninspired‚Äù column. I wouldn‚Äôt say this is a ‚Äúbad‚Äù puzzle but there isn‚Äôt anything engaging to me about it. The fill is pretty bland‚ÄîI found it easy myself but I can see where some might not have. We‚Äôve seen LAILAALI a zillion times at least as a first or last name. No clever cluing. As for the theme, I give some credit for pure anagrams, but a letter bank just seems to be pointless‚Äîanyone can make random words or phrases from a bank of letters, they don‚Äôt have anything to do with the countries involved, and PAELLAPAN and SUMMERRAIN border on ‚Äúgreen paint‚Äù for me.
One interesting crossword coincidence for me today. I only recall hearing about Shaolin monks once in my life‚Äîon Survivor: China in 2007. I just rewatched it (in my run up to their 50th season) and literally finished that yesterday. So there‚Äôs that!
Is there something more to 37D or is it just a ‚Äúwho are three people who have never been in my kitchen‚Äù kind of thing?

I liked it. Pretty easy fill (with a few look-ups of singers/writers I'll admit), but the theme was good and helped with the solve (always better than one you only need to "notice" after finishing). Clever that they were all countries, that can't have been super easy to construct.
Thanks Neville!
Has anybody commented that "pan pan" (paella pan) and "desert desert" (Sahara Desert) are both in this excellent puzzle?  Haven't seen "the the people" (the hoi polloi) for a while.
We may not all agree on the Wednesdayness of this puzzle. But, I‚Äôll go out on a limb to say Sam picked the most ‚Äúaww‚Äù inspiring photo for the column I can recall.

Solved it easily enough but was a bit underwhelmed by the theme. (Though I used the theme to help see MANOAMANO.)

SUMMERRAIN seems a bit like "Green Paint" to me, though I suppose its distinctive enough to have been used as a song title once or twice.

Had one of the themers hailed from Mozambique I suppose I'd have been more impressed. ;-)
"What's not to like" a rather unfortunate choice for this  puzzle.
An almost really nice puzzle ruined by a right side nattick

IMHOOKED was basically me last night when we suddenly realized we'd have to wait for the next episodes of Only Murders in the Building! ACK!! Silly me, I thought they'd all dropped...  Alas, no. And now the slow and painful wait from week to week. I am overcome by a deep sadness that I may never rise out of.... 

Okay, okay I might be being a wee bit dramatic, but the puzzle triggered me. Yeah, that's the ticket, it's the puzzle's fault!!

Oh, yeah, about the puzzle. Seems to not be a very popular one today but I thought it was fine and dandy! More straightforward but I don't know, I thought it was good! Admittedly, I seem to not be very puzzle critical. There are puzzles I'm extremely enthusiastic about, puzzles I really like quite a lot, or puzzles that were fun enough to do and stretched the old gray cells, as puzzles do, even if nothing to write home about. 

Guess I'm weird like that. Same with pizza and tacos... I tend to like them all‚Äîto varying degrees‚Äîbut no dislike... as long as they don't have olives. 

So, anyhow, this puzzle didn't make me shout with glee, as some do, but I quite liked it, thought the theme was cute and I enjoyed doing it. 

And now I'm picturing Bowser from Sha Na Na saying WOOF!

Fun one with a cute theme, it's nice sometimes when you can try to guess the themed answers without any crossing letters just based on your knowledge of their structure. I also enjoyed going back to do the 2012 puzzle mentioned in the write up, I thought it was pretty funny that both puzzles coincidentally had answers involving some form of MANO A MANO, not one of the more common crossword standbys.
All i can think about is Bowser from Super Mario barking like a dog
I'm Slovenian and I can confirm that we do plenty of alien invasions from here.
Much too easy for Wednesday. Barely even Tues level.
I feel like the bowser clue is a huge reach. I've never personally met a dog named bowser, nor do I associate the name with dogs in any way.

I enjoyed this one, not too easy and not too hard. Sorry there are some complaints, but I‚Äôm pretty sure I‚Äôm not alone in having enjoyed the solve. So thank you, Neville Fogarty. 
And I always enjoy Sam‚Äôs comments, but I will admit to being just a tiny bit shocked about the true nature of OnlyFans. Always surprises for me somewhere in my daily puzzle adventures.
I enjoyed the anagrams. I meant I had a typo which I found by checking one word! Good one, thanks!
Oh brother, sans the leading r.

I liked this a lot.  Not much more to say

I also like everyone else's letter bank anagrams.  Bravo all
Since the letters in the country clues can get used more than once, are they still considered anagrams?  Or is there a different word for this type of thing?

One more late puzzle find - another truly amazing one. I'll re-post this tomorrow. Anyway - a Thursday from April 3, 2014 by David Benkof and Jeff Chen. The fifteen letter reveal in that one: "Chorus starter in a 1972 David Bowie song ... or the theme of this puzzle, phonetically" CHCHCHCHCHANGES And the theme answers, all straightforwardly clued: CHANUKAHMENORAH CHAOSTHEORY CHARLOTTEBRONTE CHAINSMOKED Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/3/2014&g=36&d=A ....
Can anyone explain to me why NOUN is ‚Äúpaper or plastic, for example‚Äù other than the fact that the words are nouns??
This was fun. I liked it. I don't think I could ever construct a crossword. It seems so hard.
not my favorite at all!

Late but perhaps quite appropriate puzzle find. A Wednesday from July 10, 1985 by Fred Toole. Three fifteen letter answers - all of them appearing for the first and only time. And... two three letter answers between those fifteens. Here they are in order: NOWISTHETIMEFOR ALL GOODMENTOCOMETO THE AIDOFTHEIRPARTY Yeah. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=7/10/1985&g=17&d=A I'll probably re-post this tomorrow. ...
Decent theme with clever fill! Props for debuting ONLYFANS...too bad there isn't a country called SAN FOLOYA or something.

Huh. I just realized, reading a comment thread, that ANACIN is a brand name. For some reason I thought it was generic, like aspirin! üôà Explains why it isn't accepted in the Spelling Bee! (I usually try anacin first, then remember to enter niacin instead...)

@George

Have never agreed with you more.  I'm actually shocked at how bad a puzzle this was.  It's fit for Highlights for Children or maybe, maybe the old TV Guide.

@B

I am by no means saying you are wrong.  I'm simply trying to understand.

@Francis

It means they didn't like it ü§£

@Andrzej

üòÇ  Yeah, I know.  I guess I try to draw people out as to clues that seemed especially easy or especially hard.  Something to consider and rate.

I think there were some real no-brainers in this one, but not particularly more than I might have expected.

For example, I thought I might hear about 1A, right off the bat.  The clue is virtually a dictionary definition of BEG for dogs.
@B seems condescending. Glad this was in you wheelhouse.

@Francis

I think they mean they could have worked harder to find better fill or clues, or they didn‚Äôt put a lot of effort into making their theme better. It‚Äôs a word I would almost never use because whatever you can say about most crossword constructors, at least the one‚Äôs published here, they aren‚Äôt lazy.
@Greg4734 in Oakland Mano a Mano is Spanish for hand to hand so can be a style as well as a situation
@NYC Traveler yes! They are always fun! Easy or hard.

@Mike

I'm tired of raking leaves alone and by hand.  I need to autumn mate.
@Francis Aww Francis, you beat me to it! I thought nobody could seize on a punchline faster than me in my autumn-mobile

@Steven M. I threw in Nuprin before realizing it wasn‚Äôt nearly old enough to be associated with the first sitcom, but it was the first outdated analgesic brand I thought of other than Bromo-Seltzer, which would have had too few letters as just bromo.

@Gail

I used to live by Pepto-Bismol when I was a kid.  Looked interesting, tasted interesting, and by golly it worked on me.

I'd have really stuffed myself at a late lunch, had a miserable stomach, and needed to be ready for supper in an hour.  

Just take some Pepto-Bismol.  Like magic it worked.

@Marshall Walthew
As the columnist points out, it's called a letter bank. 
And contra the curmudgeons above, I enjoyed this. Not every puzzle needs to furrow my brow; some can just give me laugh lines.
And I was glad to see that the boxer in 10D turned out to be LAILAALI. In the same spirit, here's another sports-based clue: Scored the most goals in international soccer. ANSWER: Nope, not him. Not him either. It's Christine Sinclair of Canada. (The AI slop machine gets it wrong too.)

PS Go, Jays!

@Marshall Walthew
My first reply didn't post, so I'll just summarize.  Read the Constructor Notes.

@Marshall Walthew
Ono era, Eno?

@SBK

Would you rather get NYY or BOS?

@SBK

Thanks to all who set me straight.  My apologies for failing to read the column.

@Francis
Fortunately for all of us, I'm not playing. As a fan, I find it's always more satisfying to crush the Yanks and we certainly owned them this year. On the other hand, I suspect our boys will be happier at Fenway and, even though I will not get to any of the games (sigh), I'd rather not have our home games infested by Yankee fans. Either place is good for our big batter, Vladimir Guerrero Jr, whose bat appears to have been dipped in ice. üôÅ  So, by the slimmest of margins,I'd prefer the Bosox.

That concludes the baseball portion of this x-word discussion. Back to your puzzling ways!

Go, Jays!

@SBK

I'll be pulling for the Blue Jays all the way.
@Terry Yankees lost tonight. But it‚Äôs best of 3.

@Andrew
Where is this custom from? I've never heard of it or even seen it here. Am I just clueless?

@SBK

I'm sure I've seen a number of puzzles over the years that have clues involving anagrams and the letters are always capitalized. At any rate, I knew immediately that today's puzzles involved anagrams, making the solve much simpler than it needed to be.

@Red Carpet

Good thing you live almost exactly on the 45th parallel.

@Francis

I knew a fellow Minnesotan would understand it.

@john ezra

ü§Ø Super impressed.

@Francis, I dunno, I just pulled up a list of countries and stared at them for a while and tried to come up with some things. It's the Scrabble player in me.

Funny how little this puzzle appealed to B and George. I thought it was very pleasing.

@john ezra

That is truly amazing. I've never ever been good at solving or creating scrambled words.  I just don't have that particular gray matter, I guess.

Yes, taste is such a delicate thing.  I've disliked several that were well-received.

I guess if you want 10 different opinions about a puzzle, ask 5 solvers.

@john ezra that was magnificent! Well done, well done. 

I don‚Äôt understand the shade being thrown at this puzzle either. I like the spelling bee as well as scrabble, so what‚Äôs not to like about this?!
@john ezra Kudos!!

@john ezra

Thanks for not saying her name.

@Times Rita

My wife refers to her as Melanoma.

@john ezra

I've solved thousands of crossword puzzles and have never won a game of Scrabble and stink at Wheel of Fortune. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Brains are weird.

@Francis

I'm not a beer drinker, but I was an inveterate traveler. It helps that beer manufacturers (and cider in Ireland) stock bars with logo glasses, which I used to collect in my travels, so a lot of those names come very easily to me.

"...I am not into European beers."

Megan,

ASAHI is not a European beer.

@RozzieGrandma

I drank a lot of cider, until I realized just how much sugar and calories it has. But my then-husband had beer.
@Weak funny I did not since both were unknown to me.
... because I missed that Sam specified "country." Sports!

@Cindy
As one fan-ista to another, how did your Fever do?

@Seb
The practice technique used by singers in which the notes' names are sung, in place of nonsense syllables like tra-la-la, is called solfeggio (Ital.) or solf√®ge (Fr.). Its name is derived from sol-fa.

@Seb 

Yes, Anacin is still a household name, although not as much as it once was. They advertised heavily on US  television in its early days.

The current version is just aspirin and caffeine. 

Caffeine withdrawal usually causes a headache, but a lot of people aren't aware of that. The small amount of caffeine in many headache relief pills takes care of that very quickly, and it reinforces the idea that the pill you just took is really effective against pain.

@Seb
In the early 11th c., the Benedictine monk and music pedagogue Guido D'Arezzo, noticed that the six lines of a hymn to St. John the Baptist, "Ut queant laxis," each began with a note one tone higher than the one preceding. He used the first syllable of each line as way to have his students remember the pitches--thus "FAmuli tuorum/ SOLvi polluti." 

There have been some modifications over time, mainly adding the syllable "si," later "ti," for the seventh, leading tone; and, in some countries, changing "Ut" to "Doh."

In pronunciation, the "l" of "Sol" is usually silent.

Aren't you glad you asked?

@Andrzej a bulletin board is generally a framed piece of sheet cork (which could be quite large) onto which one attaches paper notes. In the old days thumbTACKs were used. Now it‚Äôs usually pushpins. (That is, things that go through the paper and stick into the cork.) They can be found in schools, offices and other public places to post notices (bulletins) of all varieties. In the pre-internet and app days physical bulletin boards were ubiquitous; less so today.

@Bruce
I was in HS when the Sabin sugar cube was the vaccine delivery system.  Shot in 3rd grade, right in our classroom.  One girl (Virginia Cooper, very blonde) sobbed before, during, and after.  I was so disgusted; it didn't hurt nearly as much as the shots we Army kids were subjected to!

@Barry Ancona

I had a friend who had childhood polio, too.  He'd had at least a couple of operations before he was even five.

I think it permanently changed his personality.  His limp made him the butt of jokes for much of his childhood, and I think that made him irascible, combative, something that caused problems in later life.

It was and still is sad.

So, yeah, I was very grateful for those vaccines.  I think vaccines are the greatest medical invention of mankind so far, being hundreds of thousands of times safer than the disease they protect you from.

And yet we live in an era where they are despised by so many.

@Strudel Dad Access the Globe's cryptics here: https://www.theglobeandmail.com/puzzles-and-crosswords/cryptic-crossword/ I don't think there's a paywall. My impression is that their cryptics are middling in difficulty. Duck logo swirls for fortune (4,4) -- you'll figure it out.

@SBK
The link you provided gets you to the weekday cryptic crosswords.  They are not created by Fraser Simpson but rather are from The Times (of London); hence the frequent references in those puzzles to geographical districts, rivers, towns and the like in the UK; Britishisms, and the correct (üôÇ) spelling of words like ‚Äúarmour‚Äù, ‚Äúlabour‚Äù etc.  They also have a surprisingly broad range of words hinting at anagrams.  All in all, a tad more difficult than Fraser Simpson‚Äôs Saturday cryptic crosswords. And for those of you who dare to try them, duck logo to you.

@Sonja

Same here. I spent the coldest day of my life in kindergarten.

@Sonja I don't know what the weather in Finland is like, but here on the prairie, it gets extremely brutal. The example that comes to mind is the Children's Blizzard, which killed at least 235 people, many of them children. It was an unusual event, starting as a warm day and descending into temperatures far below zero Fahrenheit. Memories of that blizzard make us wary to send our kids out in bad weather. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schoolhouse_Blizzard The idea of sending a kid out to walk to school in a blizzard is unimaginable to me. The roads are unsafe, if not impassable. Huge trucks will jackknife off the road, taking surrounding cars with them. Visibility is limited to a few feet, so it's easy to get lost, even on very short trips. The wind will strip away all your body heat and leave any exposed flesh frostbitten within less than a minute. Even as an adult, I don't go outside when it gets like that. People die every year from going out in that kind of weather.

@Sonja

My entire school career - elementary, JHS, H.S., college, then my teaching career - was in NYC. I can count on one hand (and still have fingers left) the number of times over 50 years that school were closed for any kind of storm. I'd listen to the news on the radio and hear all the school closings in New Jersey and Long Island and curse out loud!

@Sonja - The closest school of any kind to me is about 15 miles away. 

I cannot imagine a 5-year-old walking or biking that far, especially in a blizzard.

@Sonja
Living in Lake Tahoe, CA, snowstorms often make the way to school impassible, and impossible.

@Sonja
Engine block heaters are not standard here, although there are after-market options available. So if the teachers can't start their cars in the morning, school is closed. My dad grew up in Maine, and frequently cross-country skied to school. There was one big hill on the way, and the kids would wait at the bottom for a logging truck to pull them up.

@Sonja  When I first came to Germany, kids as young as three walked to their pre-schools alone. I was pretty startled the first time I encountered a little girl walking down the street with her little pink backpack who was barely taller than knee-high. Both my daughter and son did so at age four in the early nineties. Now it's a little different.  Pre-schoolers are not allowed to come without an accompanying adult until the year before they start school: age five.  All first-graders walk to school on their own, and biking is allowed after passing a test in the fourth grade.  When I go back to the U.S., I can't believe how restricted kids are. Of course, in Europe the streets are safer for pedestrians than in much of the U.S.  However, I do remember that when I was a kid in the 60s all schools had "walkers" and my own walk to the school bus stop was ten minutes on the gravel shoulder of a highway with a speed limit of 70.  How times have changed.  Personally, I blame the milk carton campaigns.

@Mean Old Lady I grew up near Seattle.  We were real weather wimps.  If there was snow more than two inches deep on the ground, it was a snow day.  It happened so seldom even back then that school bus drivers were simply not prepared to drive on slick roads.

@CaptainQuahog The difference to most of Europe is that there is public transport to schools.  I figured this out while waiting in vain for my usual bus.  It was not running because school was not in session.

@Katie
Winnipeg girl here, though self-exiled to Toronto for decades. I miss the winters out west and was very sorry to exchange an endless bowl of crisp blue sky for three months of gray slush. But the best poem I ever read about the cold pulls no punches: "Cold January Night" by Alden Nowlan. Very tough to find it online but worth the hunt. Ending is chilling in every imaginable sense.

@MExpat - That's very nice, that there's a bus!

However it is irrelevant to the comment to which I was responding. This is the relevant part:

"Also, it is very common here (at least where I've lived, can't speak for the capital) that even the very young kids WALK or BIKE to school alone." (Emphasis added by this clam.) 

Although I addressed only the WALK part, my comment would also address the BIKE part, at least for the younger students. And especially in a blizzard. 

There are not that many students out here, but I do see a school bus servicing the few that are. They don't have to walk or bike.

@Sonja I have long admired Finland's robust endurance throughout the winter months!  Up here in the far northeastern US, the frequency of calling a "snow day" can vary from town to town depending upon conditions. In my little city of Portland where we have approx. 7,000 preK - grade 12 students, the conventional wisdom always errs on the side of safety. We have a lot of students who walk to school and if the sidewalks are not cleared in time, school is often canceled to avoid having children walking in the street amidst tall snowbanks. If schools lose power that brings another huge safety and security concern regarding emergency communications.  Lastly, there is the "ice factor." We're pretty hardy up here and are used to driving in snowstorms, but if the roads are icy that can be a game changer and not safe for school buses on the road. "Snow Days" still bring an element of excitement (except for most parents) when that early morning announcement is made!‚ùÑÔ∏è

With the current gorgeous weather we've been having, however, I just as soon postpone winter for as long as possible!
